abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Dam Safety Project in
            Indonesia were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and the borrower performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: 1) to sustain
            outcomes in a situation where new concepts and processes are
            introduced, the focus on institutional development needs to
            be maintained during the project and beyond. The risk to dam
            safety in this project remains moderate or
            substantial/considerable due to relatively lower attention
            to institutional development vis-a-vis physical activities
            during implementation and inadequate follow-up thereafter;
            2) new regulatory institutions require technical expertise
            and adequate operating budgets to function in a capable and
            independent manner. In this project, shortage of
            experienced/qualified staff and inadequate operating budgets
            contributed to under-performance of the dam safety
            regulatory unit; 3) building dam safety institutions can be
            a long process when it requires major changes in
            organizational attitudes, establishing new work methods, and
            upgrading technical expertise. In such cases, the Bank
            should consider an extended commitment through a sequence of
            projects or through adaptable program lending (APL); and 4)
            new techniques and equipment should be tailored to the
            existing level of capacity; facilities and funds for ongoing
            maintenance; and site security. Most of the relatively
            sophisticated instrumentation installed at dams under this
            project has deteriorated for lack of maintenance.

10745018.trustfund:
TF035465-INDONESIA - DAM SAFETY PROJECT,TF037276-INDONESIA - DAM SAFETY,TF039329-INDONESIA - DAM SAFETY GRD
            WATER DEV; SFC PROJECTS,TF039641-INDONESIA - DAM SAFETY PROJECT
            AND GROUND WATER DEV. PROJ.,TF040767-INDONESIA: DAM SAFETY PROJECT,TF040944-INDONESIA: DAM SAFERY PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings were the following:
            Outcome is satisfactory, sustainability is likely,
            institutional development is expected to be modest, and the
            performances of the Bank and the Borrower are satisfactory.
            This project was the second stand-alone dam safety project
            financed by the Bank, and given that an Implementation
            Completion Report (ICR) for the India Dam Safety Project is
            complete its lessons are of particular interest. As in the
            case of India, the introduction of dam safety institutions
            creates requirements for unfamiliar technical specialist
            skills, a need for both a technical and regulatory
            management focus and coordination between the national level
            and the now functionally-independent provinces. Although
            many institutional teething problems were encountered and
            substantial legal and performance upgrading is still
            required, a strong start has been made in the institutional
            area.  Lessons of general and technical significance of this
            project are:   1) There is a need for realistic project
            preparation and design. 2) The project design should have
            given more emphasis to initial effective capacity-building
            before commencing the Basic Dam Safety Facility (BDSF) and
            Remedial Works components. 3) The determination of
            hydrological criteria for Probably Maximum Precipitation
            (PMPs) in different climates takes time and requires special
            study.  4) Engineering of dams is a specialized subject.
            Appropriate quality assurance arrangements need to be in
            place through an improvement of implementing agency
            management or the use of proper technical assistance with
            adequate powers and authority (task concept) to manage the
            design and construction phase. Frequent rotation of
            engineers and technicians involved in dams should be
            avoided. Those staff must have adequate training and
            experience. Training in dam safety should be
            institutionalized so that all engineers working with dams
            undergo specific personnel capacity-building training. 5) It
            is important to establish priorities for remedial works
            investments, and appropriate risk analysis needs to be used,
            based on public hazard and dam safety condition criteria. 6)
            The preparation team should have been instructed not to
            accept the MPW Inspectorate General as the source for
            technical audit, as this unit is a financial auditor and
            incapable of undertaking technical audits, even with
            technical assistance. 7) A model Operation and Maintenance
            Manual incorporating dam safety considerations needs to be
            prepared early in the project for guidance.

18218536.theme: Water resource management,Environmental policies and institutions
18218536.trustfund:
TF035465-INDONESIA - DAM SAFETY PROJECT,TF039329-INDONESIA - DAM SAFETY GRD
            WATER DEV; SFC PROJECTS,TF040767-INDONESIA: DAM SAFETY PROJECT,TF039641-INDONESIA - DAM SAFETY PROJECT
            AND GROUND WATER DEV. PROJ.,TF040944-INDONESIA: DAM SAFERY PROJECT,TF037276-INDONESIA - DAM SAFETY

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Dam Safety
            Project is to reduce the risk of dam failures in Indonesia
            through establishment of national dam safety institutions
            and carrying out a program to improve the safety of existing
            dams. The project includes the following main components:
            (a) support for the recently established Dam Safety
            Commission (DSC) and Dam Safety Unit (DSU) at central
            government level and Dam Monitoring Units (DMU) at central
            and local dam owners' levels; (b) provision of basic
            dam safety facilities at dams where at present such
            facilities are lacking; and (c) implementation of remedial
            works at dams with safety deficiencies. Training and
            technical assistance will be provided to assist the
            Directorate General of Water Resources Development with the
            implementation of the project.
